papers.title: Automated Repair of Code from Language Models
papers.authors: Zhiyu Fan,Xiang Gao,M. Mirchev,Abhik Roychoudhury,Shin Hwei Tan
papers.summary: The study revealed that automatically generated code shares common programming mistakes with human-crafted solutions, indicating APR techniques may have potential to auto-generated code, and given bug location information provided by a statistical fault localization approach, Codex edit mode is similar to or better than existing Java repair tools TBar and Recoder in correcting incorrect solutions.

papers.title: Automated Repair of Programs from Large Language Models
papers.authors: Zhiyu Fan,Xiang Gao,M. Mirchev,Abhik Roychoudhury,Shin Hwei Tan
papers.summary: The study revealed that automatically generated code shares common programming mistakes with human-crafted solutions, indicating APR techniques may have potential to auto-generated code, and given bug location information provided by a statistical fault localization approach, Codex edit mode is similar to or better than existing Java repair tools TBar and Recoder in correcting incorrect solutions.

papers.title: Improving automatically generated code from Codex via Automated Program Repair
papers.authors: Zhiyu Fan,Xiang Gao,Abhik Roychoudhury,Shin Hwei Tan
papers.summary: This study systematically study whether automated program repair (APR) techniques can fix the incorrect solutions produced by language models in LeetCode contests, revealing that automatically generated codes share some common programming mistakes with human-crafted solutions, indicating existing APR tools have the potential to fix auto-generated code.

papers.title: Recommending Root-Cause and Mitigation Steps for Cloud Incidents using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Toufique Ahmed,Supriyo Ghosh,Chetan Bansal,T. Zimmermann,Xuchao Zhang,S. Rajmohan
papers.summary: A rigorous study on the effectiveness of large language models for helping engineers root cause and mitigate production incidents, and a human evaluation with actual incident owners show the future potential of using artiﬁcial intelligence for resolving cloud incidents.

papers.title: Fooling MOSS Detection with Pretrained Language Models
papers.venue: International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management
papers.authors: Stella Rose Biderman,Edward Raff
papers.summary: It is found that a student using GPT-J can complete introductory level programming assignments without triggering suspicion from MOSS, a widely used software similarity and plagiarism detection tool.

papers.title: A Scalable and Extensible Approach to Benchmarking NL2Code for 18 Programming Languages
papers.authors: Federico Cassano,John Gouwar,Daniel Nguyen,S. Nguyen,Luna Phipps-Costin,Donald Pinckney,Ming-Ho Yee,Yangtian Zi,Carolyn Jane Anderson,Molly Q. Feldman,Arjun Guha,M. Greenberg,Abhinav Jangda
papers.summary: It is shown that on several languages, Codex matches and even exceeds its performance on Python, and a general approach is described for easily adding support for new benchmarks and languages to MultiPL-E, the first multi-language parallel benchmark for natural-language-to-code-generation.

papers.title: Diverse Title Generation for Stack Overflow Posts with Multiple Sampling Enhanced Transformer
papers.authors: Fengji Zhang,Jin Liu,Yao Wan,Xiao Yu,Xiao Liu,J. Keung
papers.summary: A novel approach to automatically generate multiple post titles from the given code snippets, using the maximal marginal multiple nucleus sampling strategy to generate multiple high-quality and diverse title candidates at a time for the developers to choose from.

papers.title: Explicit Knowledge Transfer for Weakly-Supervised Code Generation
papers.authors: Zhangir Azerbayev,Ansong Ni,Hailey Schoelkopf,Dragomir R. Radev
papers.summary: It is shown that EKT not only yields better performance than training with expert iteration, but also outperforms knowledge distillation, another form of knowledge transfer, and it is possible for a student model to outperform the teacher using EKT.

papers.title: The Premature Obituary of Programming
papers.authors: D. Yellin
papers.summary: Why deep learning will not replace programming and why deep learning should not be considered as a programming language.

papers.title: P LANNING WITH L ARGE L ANGUAGE M ODELS FOR C ODE G ENERATION
papers.summary: A novel Transformer decoding algorithm that uses a planning algorithm to do lookahead search and guide the Transformer to generate better programs, and enables controllable code generation, such as concise codes and highly-commented codes by optimizing modified objectives.

papers.title: C ODE S UMMARIZATION : D O T RANSFORMERS R E ALLY U C
papers.authors: Manasi S. Patwardhan,L. Vig,Raveendra Kumar Medicherla,Ravindra Naik,Gautam M. Shroff
papers.summary: Overall, the quality of the generated summaries even from state-of-the-art (SOTA) models is quite poor, raising questions about the utility of current approaches and datasets.

papers.title: Understanding High-Level Properties of Low-Level Programs Through Transformers
papers.authors: William S. Moses
papers.summary: It is shown that Transformer models can translate C to LLVM-IR with high accuracy, by training on a parallel corpus of functions extract from 1 million compilable, open-sourced C programs and its corresponding LL VM-IR after compiling with Clang.

papers.title: Enabling Transformers to Understand Low-Level Programs
papers.venue: IEEE Conference on High Performance Extreme Computing
papers.authors: Zifan Carl Guo,William S. Moses
papers.summary: This work applies transfer learning to low-level (LLVM) programs and study how low- level programs can be made more amenable to Transformer models through various techniques, including preprocessing, infix/prefix operators, and information deduplication.

papers.title: Large Language Models are Few-shot Testers: Exploring LLM-based General Bug Reproduction
papers.authors: Sungmin Kang,Juyeon Yoon,Shin Yoo
papers.summary: Results show L IBRO has the potential to enhance developerency by automatically generating tests from bug reports, and is proposed as a framework that uses Large Language Models (LLMs), which have been shown to be capable of performing code-related tasks.

papers.title: An Empirical Study of Code Smells in Transformer-based Code Generation Techniques
papers.venue: IEEE Working Conference on Source Code Analysis and Manipulation
papers.authors: Mohammed Latif Siddiq,Shafayat H. Majumder,Maisha R. Mim,Sourov Jajodia,Joanna C. S. Santos
papers.summary: This study investigates to what extent code smells are present in the datasets of coding generation techniques and verify whether they leak into the output of these techniques.

papers.title: Language Models of Code are Few-Shot Commonsense Learners
papers.authors: Aman Madaan,Shuyan Zhou,Uri Alon,Yiming Yang,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: This paper shows that when this task is frame as code generation tasks, pre-trained LMs of code are better structured commonsense reasoners than L Ms of natural language, even when the downstream task does not involve source code at all.

papers.title: ObSynth: An Interactive Synthesis System for Generating Object Models from Natural Language Specifications
papers.authors: Alex Gu,Tamara Mitrovska,D. Vélez,Jacob Andreas,Armando Solar-Lezama
papers.summary: ObSynth is introduced, an interactive system leveraging the domain knowledge em-bedded in large language models (LLMs) to help users design object models from high level natural language prompts, showing that it often synthesizes objects, methods, and methods users might have otherwise omitted.

papers.title: Large Language Models Are Human-Level Prompt Engineers
papers.authors: Yongchao Zhou,Andrei Ioan Muresanu,Ziwen Han,Keiran Paster,Silviu Pitis,Harris Chan,Jimmy Ba
papers.summary: It is shown that APE-engineered prompts can be applied to steer models toward truthfulness and/or informativeness, as well as to improve few-shot learning performance by simply prepending them to standard in-context learning prompts.

papers.title: Don't Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments
papers.authors: Yu Gu,Xiang Deng,Yu Su
papers.summary: Pangu is proposed, a generic framework for grounded language understanding that capitalizes on the discriminative ability of LMs instead of their generative ability, and enables, for the first time, effective few-shot in-context learning for KBQA with large LMs such as Codex.

papers.title: A Survey of Deep Learning for Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Liang Qiu,Wenhao Yu,S. Welleck,Kai-Wei Chang
papers.summary: This survey paper reviews the key tasks, datasets, and methods at the intersec-tion of mathematical reasoning and deep learning over the past decade, and evaluates existing benchmarks and methods and discusses future research directions.

papers.title: TrojanPuzzle: Covertly Poisoning Code-Suggestion Models
papers.authors: H. Aghakhani,Wei Dai,Andre Manoel,Xavier Fernandes,Anant Kharkar,Christopher Kruegel,Giovanni Vigna,David Evans,B. Zorn,Robert Sim
papers.summary: Two novel data poisoning attacks are demonstrated, C OVERT and T ROJAN P UZZLE, that can bypass static analysis by planting malicious poisoning data in out-of-context regions such as docstrings and have implications for how practitioners should select code used to be coded.

papers.title: Towards a Mathematics Formalisation Assistant using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Ayush Agrawal,Siddhartha Gadgil,Navin Goyal,Ashvni Narayanan,Anand Tadipatri
papers.summary: The abilities of a large language model (Codex) to help with formalisation in the Lean theorem prover are explored, finding that with careful inputdependent prompt selection and postprocessing, Codex is able to formalise short mathematical statements at undergrad level with nearly 75% accuracy for 120 theorem statements.

papers.title: Show Your Work: Scratchpads for Intermediate Computation with Language Models
papers.authors: Maxwell Nye,Anders Andreassen,Guy Gur-Ari,H. Michalewski,Jacob Austin,David Bieber,David Dohan,Aitor Lewkowycz,Maarten Bosma,D. Luan,Charles Sutton,Augustus Odena
papers.summary: Surprisingly, large pre-trained language models are able to perform complex multistep computations—even in the few-shot regime—when asked to perform the operation “step by step”, showing the results of intermediate computations.

papers.title: Examining Zero-Shot Vulnerability Repair with Large Language Models
papers.authors: H. Pearce,B. Tan,Baleegh Ahmad,R. Karri,Brendan Dolan-Gavitt
papers.summary: This work examines the use of large language models for code (such as OpenAI’s Codex and AI21's Jurassic J-1) for zero-shot vulnerability repair, and investigates challenges in the design of prompts that coax LLMs into generating repaired versions of insecure code.

papers.title: Can OpenAI Codex and Other Large Language Models Help Us Fix Security Bugs?
papers.authors: H. Pearce,B. Tan,Baleegh Ahmad,R. Karri,Brendan Dolan-Gavitt
papers.summary: This work examines the use of large language models for code (such as OpenAI's Codex and AI21's Jurassic J-1) for zero-shot vulnerability repair, and investigates challenges in the design of prompts that coax LLMs into generating repaired versions of insecure code.

papers.title: C OMPOSITIONAL G ENERALIZATION AND D ECOMPOSITION IN N EURAL P ROGRAM S YNTHESIS
papers.summary: A suite of generalization tasks, which measure different types of compositional generalization that are desirable for program synthesis and are particularly difﬁcult for current sequence to sequence models, are proposed.

papers.title: Generation Probabilities are Not Enough: Improving Error Highlighting for AI Code Suggestions
papers.authors: Helena Vasconcelos
papers.summary: It is unclear how best to convey the uncertainty of generative models to human operators or if doing so will positively impact human-AI collaboration.

papers.title: P ATCH G ENERATION WITH L ANGUAGE M ODELS : F EASIBILITY AND S CALING B EHAVIOR
papers.authors: Sophia Kolak,Ruben Martins,Claire Le Goues,V. Hellendoorn
papers.summary: This work highlights a noticeable correlation of model size with test-passing accuracy and patch ranking quality, and the propensity for especially the largest models to generate candidate patches that closely resemble (if not exactly match), the original developer patch.

papers.title: Open-Ended Knowledge Tracing for Computer Science Education
papers.authors: Naiming Liu,Zichao Wang
papers.summary: This paper develops an initial solution to the OKT problem, a student knowledge-guided code generation approach that combines program synthesis methods using language models with student knowledge tracing methods and conducts a series of quantitative and qualitative experiments to validate OKT and demonstrate its promise in educational applications.

papers.title: Leveraging Automated Unit Tests for Unsupervised Code Translation
papers.authors: Baptiste Rozière,J Zhang,François Charton,M. Harman,Gabriel Synnaeve,Guillaume Lample
papers.summary: This work proposes to leverage an automated unit-testing system to filter out invalid translations, thereby creating a fully tested parallel corpus, and finds that fine-tuning an unsupervised model with this filtered data set significantly reduces the noise in the translations so-generated, comfortably outperforming the state of the art for all language pairs studied.

papers.title: Large Language Models are not Models of Natural Language: they are Corpus Models.
papers.authors: C. Veres
papers.summary: It is argued that the term language model is misleading because deep learning models are not theoretical models of language and proposed the adoption of corpus model instead, which better reflects the genesis and contents of the model.

papers.title: Open-Ended Knowledge Tracing
papers.authors: Naiming Liu,Zichao Wang,Richard Baraniuk,Andrew S. Lan
papers.summary: This paper develops an initial solution to the OKT problem, a student knowledge-guided code generation approach that combines program synthesis methods using language models with student knowledge tracing methods and conducts a series of quantitative and qualitative experiments on a real-world student code dataset to validate OKT and demonstrate its promise in educational applications.

papers.title: The impact of lexical and grammatical processing on generating code from natural language
papers.authors: Nathanael Beau,Benoit Crabb'e
papers.summary: The paper highlights the importance of the lexical substitution component in the current natural language to code systems with a state-of-the-art architecture that relies on BERT encoder and a grammar-based decoder for which a formalization is provided.

papers.title: MCoNaLa: A Benchmark for Code Generation from Multiple Natural Languages
papers.authors: Zhiruo Wang,Grace Cuenca,Shuyan Zhou,Frank F. Xu,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: A multilingual dataset, MCoNaLa, is proposed to benchmark code generation from natural language commands extending beyond English, and a quantitative evaluation of performance on the M coNaLa dataset is presented by testing with state-of-theart code generation systems.

papers.title: A Conversational Paradigm for Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Erik Nijkamp,Bo Pang,Hiroaki Hayashi,Lifu Tu,Haiquan Wang,Yingbo Zhou,S. Savarese,Caiming Xiong
papers.summary: This work proposes and trains C ODE G EN, an interactive code generation model for program synthesis, and suggests that the capacity of conversational program synthesis scales as a function of the model size and data size.

papers.title: PaLM: Scaling Language Modeling with Pathways
papers.authors: Aakanksha Chowdhery,Sharan Narang,Jacob Devlin,Maarten Bosma,Gaurav Mishra,Adam Roberts,P. Barham,Hyung Won Chung,Charles Sutton,Sebastian Gehrmann,Parker Schuh,Kensen Shi,Sasha Tsvyashchenko,Joshua Maynez,Abhishek Rao,Parker Barnes,Yi Tay,Noam M. Shazeer,Vinodkumar Prabhakaran,Emily Reif,Nan Du,B. Hutchinson,Reiner Pope,James Bradbury,Jacob Austin,M. Isard,Guy Gur-Ari,Pengcheng Yin,Toju Duke,Anselm Levskaya,S. Ghemawat,Sunipa Dev,H. Michalewski,Xavier García,Vedant Misra,Kevin Robinson,L. Fedus,Denny Zhou,Daphne Ippolito,D. Luan,Hyeontaek Lim,Barret Zoph,A. Spiridonov,Ryan Sepassi,David Dohan,Shivani Agrawal,Mark Omernick,Andrew M. Dai,T. S. Pillai,Marie Pellat,Aitor Lewkowycz,Erica Moreira,Rewon Child,Oleksandr Polozov,Katherine Lee,Zongwei Zhou,Xuezhi Wang,Brennan Saeta,Mark Díaz,Orhan Firat,Michele Catasta,Jason Wei,K. Meier-Hellstern,D. Eck,J. Dean,Slav Petrov,Noah Fiedel
papers.summary: A 540-billion parameter, densely activated, Transformer language model, which is called PaLM achieves breakthrough performance, outperforming the state-of-the-art on a suite of multi-step reasoning tasks, and outperforming average human performance on the recently released BIG-bench benchmark.

papers.title: Compositional Generalization and Decomposition in Neural Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Kensen Shi,Joey Hong,M. Zaheer,Pengcheng Yin,Charles Sutton
papers.summary: A suite of generalization tasks, which measure different types of compositional generalization that are desirable for program synthesis and are particularly difﬁcult for current sequence to sequence models, are proposed.

papers.title: CodexDB: Generating Code for Processing SQL Queries using GPT-3 Codex
papers.authors: Immanuel Trummer
papers.summary: CodexDB is a framework on top of GPT-3 Codex that decomposes complex SQL queries into a series of simple processing steps, described in natural language, enriched with user-provided instructions and descriptions of database properties.

papers.title: Passport: Improving Automated Formal Verification Using Identifiers
papers.authors: Alex Sanchez-Stern,E. First,Timothy Zhou,Zhanna Kaufman,Yuriy Brun,T. Ringer
papers.summary: Passport is a fully-automated proof-synthesis tool that encodes one additional aspect of that rich proof data: identifiers, suggesting that modeling identifiers can play a significant role in improving proof synthesis, leading to higher-quality software.

papers.title: Neural language models for network configuration: Opportunities and reality check
papers.authors: Zied Ben-Houidi,Dario Rossi
papers.summary: Recent advances in deep learning applied to programming languages are surveyed, for the purpose of code veriﬁcation, synthesis and translation: in particularly, their training requirements and expected performance are reviewed, and qualitatively assess whether similar techniques can bene⬁t corresponding use-cases in networking.

papers.title: NaturalProver: Grounded Mathematical Proof Generation with Language Models
papers.authors: S. Welleck,Jiacheng Liu,Ximing Lu,Hannaneh Hajishirzi,Yejin Choi
papers.summary: N ATURAL P ROVER is capable of proving some theorems that require short (2-6 step) proofs, and providing next-step suggestions that are rated as correct and useful over 40% of the time, which is to the authors' knowledge the first demonstration of these capabilities using neural language models.

papers.title: FixEval: Execution-based Evaluation of Program Fixes for Competitive Programming Problems
papers.authors: Md. Mahim Anjum Haque,W. Ahmad,Ismini Lourentzou,Chris Brown
papers.summary: This work introduces F IX E VAL, a benchmark comprising of buggy code submissions to competitive programming problems and their respective ﬁxes, and believes it provides a step towards real-world automatic bugﬁxing and model-generated code evaluation.

papers.title: AixBench: A Code Generation Benchmark Dataset
papers.authors: Yiyang Hao,Ge Li,Yongqiang Liu,Xiaowei Miao,He Zong,Siyuan Jiang,Yang Liu,He Wei
papers.summary: A benchmark dataset for evaluating method-level code generation task and a new metric for automatically evaluating the correctness of the generated code, and a set of criteria to manually evaluating the overall quality of thegenerated code are presented.

papers.title: Solving Quantitative Reasoning Problems with Language Models
papers.authors: Aitor Lewkowycz,Anders Andreassen,David Dohan,Ethan Dyer,H. Michalewski,V. Ramasesh,Ambrose Slone,Cem Anil,Imanol Schlag,Theo Gutman-Solo,Yuhuai Wu,Behnam Neyshabur,Guy Gur-Ari,Vedant Misra

papers.title: GitHub Copilot AI pair programmer: Asset or Liability?
papers.authors: Arghavan Moradi Dakhel,Vahid Majdinasab,Amin Nikanjam,F. Khomh,M. Desmarais,Z. Jiang
papers.summary: Comparing Copilot to humans, the results show that the correct ratio of human solutions is greater than Copilot’s correct ratio, while the buggy solutions generated by Copilot require less time to be repaired.

papers.title: Grounded Copilot: How Programmers Interact with Code-Generating Models
papers.authors: Shraddha Barke,M. James,N. Polikarpova
papers.summary: Interactions with programming assistants are bimodal : in acceleration mode , the programmer knows what to do next and uses Copilot to get there faster; in exploration mode, the programmer is unsure how to proceed and usesCopilot to explore their options.

papers.title: How Readable is Model-generated Code? Examining Readability and Visual Inspection of GitHub Copilot
papers.venue: International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: N. A. Madi
papers.summary: The results suggest that model generated code is comparable in complexity and readability to code written by human pair programmers, and eye tracking data suggests, to a statistically significant level, that programmers direct less visual attention to model generate code.

papers.title: I Speak, You Verify: Toward Trustworthy Neural Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Darren Key,Wen-Ding Li,Kevin Ellis
papers.summary: An approach for improving the trustworthiness and overall accuracy of program synthesizers based on large language models for source code by analyzing the agreement between programs and predicates to judge both which program is most likely to be correct and whether the language model is able to solve the programming problem in the first place.

papers.title: Repairing Bugs in Python Assignments Using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Jialu Zhang,J. Cambronero,Sumit Gulwani,Vu Le,R. Piskac,Gustavo Soares,Gust Verbruggen
papers.summary: This work proposes to use a large language model trained on code, such as Codex, to build an APR system – MMAPR – for introductory Python programming assignments and finds that MM APR can produce more programs and produce smaller patches on average.

papers.title: ContraGen: Effective Contrastive Learning For Causal Language Model
papers.authors: Nihal Jain,Dejiao Zhang,Wasi Uddin Ahmad,Zijian Wang,Feng Nan,Xiaopeng Li,M. Tan,Ramesh Nallapati,Baishakhi Ray,Parminder Bhatia,Xiaofei Ma,Bing Xiang
papers.summary: It is shown that C ONTRA G EN can effectively enhance both uniformity and discrimination of the representations and lead to the desired improvement on various language understanding tasks where discriminative representations are crucial for attaining good performance.

papers.title: FlexType: A Plug-and-Play Framework for Type Inference Models
papers.venue: International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: Sivani Voruganti,Kevin Jesse,Prem Devanbu
papers.summary: This work introduces FlexType, an IDE extension that can be used on both JavaScript and TypeScript to infer types in an interactive or automatic fashion and believes the interactive Visual Studio Code extension is inherently useful in both TypeScript and JavaScript especially when resolving types is taxing for the developer.

papers.title: How Readable is Model-generated Code? Examining Readability and Visual Inspection of GitHub Copilot
papers.venue: 37th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: Naser Al Madi
papers.summary: The results suggest that model generated code is comparable in complexity and readability to code written by human pair programmers, and eye tracking data suggests, to a statistically significant level, that programmers direct less visual attention to model generate code.

papers.title: Challenging BIG-Bench Tasks and Whether Chain-of-Thought Can Solve Them
papers.authors: Mirac Suzgun,Nathan Scales,Nathanael Scharli,Sebastian Gehrmann,Yi Tay,Hyung Won Chung,Aakanksha Chowdhery,Quoc V. Le,E. Chi,Denny Zhou,Jason Wei
papers.summary: It is found that applying chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting to BBH tasks enables PaLM to surpass the average human-rater performance on 10 of the 23 tasks, and Codex to surpass it on 17 of the23 tasks.

papers.title: Transformers Learn Shortcuts to Automata
papers.authors: Bingbin Liu,J. Ash,Surbhi Goel,A. Krishnamurthy,Cyril Zhang
papers.summary: The theoretical results completely characterize shortcut solutions, whereby a shallow Transformer with only o(T ) layers can exactly replicate the computation of an automaton on an input sequence of length T .

papers.title: Practical Program Repair in the Era of Large Pre-trained Language Models
papers.authors: Chun Xia,Yuxiang Wei,Lingming Zhang
papers.summary: This study demonstrates that directly applying state-of-the-art PLMs can already substantially outperform all existing APR techniques on all the authors' datasets and shows that PLM-based APR can be further substantially boosted via: increasing the sample size, and incorporating inﬁx template information.

papers.title: SecurityEval dataset: mining vulnerability examples to evaluate machine learning-based code generation techniques
papers.authors: Mohammed Latif Siddiq,msiddiq
papers.summary: SecurityEval, an evaluation dataset that contains 130 samples for 75 vulnerability types, which are mapped to the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) and demonstrated using one open-source and one closed-source code generation model to evaluate.

papers.title: BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model
papers.authors: Teven Le Scao,Angela Fan,Christopher Akiki,Elizabeth-Jane Pavlick,Suzana Ili'c,Daniel Hesslow,Roman Castagn'e,A. Luccioni,Franccois Yvon,Matthias Gallé,J. Tow,Alexander M. Castillo,Marianna Nezhurina,Mario Sanger,M. Samwald,Michael Cullan,Michael Weinberg,M. Wolf,Mina Mihaljcic,Minna Liu,M. Freidank,Myungsun Kang,Natasha Seelam,N. Dahlberg,N. Broad,N.
